provenance: Pierre Mariette, Paris, 1667 (cf. Lugt 1789, 1634-1716); [Craddock and Barnard, London]; Sale, Sotheby's, London, March 30, 2010, part of no. 8, to MIA
signed: at bottom edge, in the plate: [Annibal Caracius in fe. Caprarole. 1597. Nico Van Aelst for.]; on back, in brown ink: [Mariette 1667]
text: It is nearly impossible to imagine the history of European art without the genius of Annibale Carracci. In the late 16th century, he emerged as one of the leading artists in Italy, breaking away from the mannerist style that had predominated the last fifty years of art making. His novel introduction of naturalism to religious art struck a chord in Counter-Reformation Italy, and he elevated his artistic vocabulary with a classicizing grandeur inspired by the Antique and the Renaissance.
